com.hannesdorfmann.mosby3.mvp

Class MvpBasePresenter<V extends MvpView>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hannesdorfmann.mosby3.mvp.MvpBasePresenter<V>
  • Type Parameters:
    V - type of the MvpView
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    MvpPresenter<V>

    public class MvpBasePresenter<V extends MvpView>
extends java.lang.Object
implements MvpPresenter<V>
    A base implementation of a MvpPresenter that uses a WeakReference for referring to the attached view.

    Use ifViewAttached(ViewAction) to interact with the view. Since the view is passive, usually a Presenter should not get any data from View: so calls like view.getUserId() should not be done. Rather write a method in your Presenter that takes the user id as parameter like this: void doSomething(int userId){ // do something ... ifViewAttached( view -> view.showSuccessful()) }

    Since:
    1.0.0

      • getView

        @Deprecated
public V getView()
        Deprecated. Use ifViewAttached(ViewAction)
        Get the attached view. You should always call isViewAttached() to check if the view is attached to avoid NullPointerExceptions.
        Returns:
        null, if view is not attached, otherwise the concrete view instance

      • isViewAttached

        @Deprecated
public boolean isViewAttached()
        Deprecated. Use ifViewAttached(ViewAction)
        Checks if a view is attached to this presenter. You should always call this method before calling getView() to get the view instance.

      • detachView

        @Deprecated
public void detachView(boolean retainInstance)
        Deprecated. 
        Will be called if the view has been destroyed. Typically this method will be invoked from Activity.detachView() or Fragment.onDestroyView()
        Specified by:
        detachView in interface MvpPresenter<V extends MvpView>

      • ifViewAttached

        protected final void ifViewAttached(boolean exceptionIfViewNotAttached,
                                    MvpBasePresenter.ViewAction<V> action)
        Executes the passed Action only if a View is attached. if no view is attached either an exception will be thrown if parameter exceptionIfViewNotAttached is true. Otherwise, the action is just not executed (no exception thrown). Note that if no view is attached this will not re-executed the given action if the View get's re attached.
        Parameters:
        exceptionIfViewNotAttached - true, if an exception should be thrown if no view is attached while trying to execute the action. false, if no exception should be thrown (but action will not executed either since no view attached)
        action - The MvpBasePresenter.ViewAction that will be executed if a view is attached. Here is where you call view.isLoading etc. Use the view reference passed as parameter to MvpBasePresenter.ViewAction.run(Object) and not deprecated method getView()

      • ifViewAttached

        protected final void ifViewAttached(MvpBasePresenter.ViewAction<V> action)
        Calls ifViewAttached(boolean, ViewAction) with false as first parameter (don't throw exception if view not attached).
        See Also:
        ifViewAttached(boolean, ViewAction)

      • detachView

        public void detachView()
        Will be called if the view has been detached from the Presenter. Usually this happens on screen orientation changes or view (like fragment) has been put on the backstack.
        Specified by:
        detachView in interface MvpPresenter<V extends MvpView>

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Will be called if the presenter is no longer needed because the View has been destroyed permanently. This is where you do clean up stuff.
        Specified by:
        destroy in interface MvpPresenter<V extends MvpView>
